title: The Curious Case of Chuck E. Cheese — AKA Pasqually’s Pizza and Wings

data.content: Rebranding as business survival or guerrilla marketing?
https://miro.medium.com/max/9856/0*MST4VDa7HPGM6G0p
Chuck E. Cheese is a venerable chain of family entertainment/restaurants that has been a staple of kids’ birthday parties for decades.
My childhood memories are littered with birthday parties at Chuck E. Cheese — a wonderland filled with videogames, jungle gyms, and ball pits, as well as pizza.
It was essentially a non-alcoholic, child-friendly version of Dave and Busters.
I loved it. I hadn’t thought about it in years.

And yet, Chuck E. Cheese was trending on Twitter on Monday morning after certain users discovered the chain had re-branded itself on delivery app GrubHub, in order to win more business for its takeout pizza and other junk food.
It was now…
Pasqually’s Pizza and Wings
Obviously, this revelation was tailor-made for Twitter.
Folks were quick to criticize Chuck E. Cheese for effectively attempting to catfish unsuspecting customers into ordering its sub-par food.
It turns out this charade had been going on for at least a month.
The story of Pasqually’s broke on Reddit back in April and was the subject of a brilliantly snarky write-up in Food & Wine.
The new name has a connection to the original brand as well — Pasqually P. Pieplate is the name of the fictional (human) chef and friend to Chuck E. Cheese, the titular cartoon mouse.
Better still, when the writer for Food & Wine reached out to Chuck E. Cheese for comment, a spokesperson played off the new name as the legitimate launch of a sister brand, saying:

“… It is a different pizza that features a thicker crust and extra sauce, giving consumers a more flavorful, more premium pizza experience. While Pasqually’s Pizza & Wings recipes are currently only available for delivery, select items might be added to the Chuck E. Cheese menu in the future.”

Whether this was a legitimate attempt to re-brand as a viable take-out restaurant or just a brilliant piece of guerrilla marketing, Chuck E. Cheese achieved remarkable marketing lift from the stunt and did the impossible — it got people talking about them again.
Either way, Chuck E. Cheese himself should be careful, as the cat’s now out of the bag.
Payless Or Palessi?
This is not the first time in recent years that a major discount brand has launched a fake, higher-end sister brand.

Payless ShoeSource made headlines in November 2018 when it opened a fake luxury store in Los Angeles called Palessi. They then invited 60 fashion influencers to the store’s soft launch, granting them exclusive early access to the luxury shoes — priced as high as $600+ a pair.
In reality, every one of the items on sale retailed at Payless for $19.99 — $39.99.

The fashion influencers were duped — and many were even quoted on camera raving about the quality of their newly-bought wares — before being informed that they had just spent hundreds of dollars apiece on common (and far cheaper) Payless items.
PR firm DCX Growth Accelerator masterminded the Palessi campaign, which included not just the storefront in the high-end mall, but also the creation of a website for the fake luxury brand.
In this case, the stunt was short-lived, as the Payless team informed the influencers that they had just been duped before they left the premises (and, refunding their money, naturally).
But as a marketing stunt? It was both brilliant and effective.
The story of Palessi was covered in outlets including ABC News, CBS News, The Washington Post, Elle, AdWeek, Vox, and many more — and just in time for the holiday season.
While this was a clear win for the brand in the short term, it did not save the company.
In February 2019, the brand confirmed it would close its stores — by July 2019, all 2,100+ locations in the U.S. and Puerto Rico were gone.
Ice Tea Distributor Or Bitcoin Speculator?
A third example of successful marketing via a re-brand came in 2017 when Long Island Ice Tea Corp. changed its name to Long Blockchain Corp.
The was the height of the blockchain bubble — when Bitcoin was trading at more than $19,000.

The day Long Island Ice Tea Corp. announced its name change, its share price shot up 500% in pre-market trading. In addition to changing its name (and website URL), the company claimed that this was a true strategic pivot.

Long Blockchain said that it would continue to sell non-alcoholic ice teas and lemonades as a subsidiary, but its primary focus would be on partnering with companies involved in blockchain technology.
The claim was short-lived.

Less than two months later, Long Blockchain admitted it was not close to closing any blockchain-related partnerships, and its stock price had fallen 50% from the heights it had achieved the day it simply announced the name change.
And by last summer, the FBI was investigating the company on charges that the name change and “strategic pivot” was simply a charade to mask a complex insider trading scheme.
Lessons
The first critical step in marketing is simply building customer awareness — to get people to not only recognize — but also talk about — your brand.
And building awareness is more challenging than ever in this age of declining attention spans, and the increasing influence of social media, influencers, and pure information overload.
It’s truly difficult to break through the noise.

But two of the three stories above illustrate that the re-brand campaigns were born of desperation rather than creativity — these were not just brilliant marketing campaigns, they were also the last gasps of struggling brands.
Truly brilliant marketing requires creativity, but not in a way that either ignores or alienates your core customer base.
And if the business fundamentals aren’t sound, to begin with, no amount of clever marketing will save you.
